bestBHT.bht: And I said, What shall I do, Lord? This is the voice of a tamed man, who has truly turned to the Lord and seeks His guidance. Paul's response exemplifies the beginning of well-doing, for he asks the mouth of God for direction. It is a reminder to all that labor is futile if one attempts to embark on the path of repentance without consulting His word. God does not blind those whom He wishes to enlighten, but it is a reminder that we must humble ourselves and seek His wisdom, for anyone who strives to be wise in their own eyes will only become foolish in His sight.

John Calvin: What shall I do, Lord? This is the voice of a tamed man, and this is the true turning unto the Lord.
Moreover, this is the beginning of well-doing, to ask the mouth of God; for their labor is lost who think upon repentance without his word.
God doth not indeed make blind all those whom he will lighten; but there is a general rule prescribed to all men, that those become foolish with themselves who will be wise to him.
Archibald T. Robertson: Into Damascus (εις Δαμασκον). In Acts 9:6 simply 'into the city' (εις την πολιν)."
Of all things which (περ παντων ων). Hων, relative plural attracted to genitive of antecedent from accusative α, object of ποιησα (do)."

Are appointed for thee (τετακτα σο). Perfect passive indicative of τασσω, to appoint, to order, with dative σο. Compare with οτ σε δε of Acts 9:6. The words were spoken to Paul, of course, in the Aramaic, Saoul, Saoul.
John Gill: And I said, what shall I do, Lord?....

And I said, What shall I do, Lord? This is the voice of a tamed man, who has truly turned to the Lord and seeks His guidance. Paul's response reflects the beginning of well-doing, as he acknowledges the necessity of seeking the mouth of God for direction. It serves as a reminder that labor is in vain without consulting His word. God does not blind those whom He desires to enlighten, but rather imparts wisdom to those who humble themselves and rely on Him for guidance.

And I said, What shall I do, Lord? This is the voice of a tamed man, who has truly turned to the Lord and seeks His guidance. Paul's response exemplifies the beginning of well-doing, for he asks the mouth of God for direction. It is a reminder to all that labor is futile if one attempts to embark on the path of repentance without consulting His word. It serves as a reminder that labor is in vain without consulting His word. God does not blind those whom He desires to enlighten, but rather imparts wisdom to those who humbly ask for it.
